metadata.case_name: Distant Agnate of Sheo Ghulam v. Murlidhar (Nephew)

facts.text: One Sheo Ghulam, a pious Hindu and resident of village Bhadesia, District Sitapur, constructed Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji during 1914-1916 and installed idol ceremoniously.
Sheo Ghulam managed temple till his death in 1928 without issue.

On March 6, 1919, Sheo Ghulam executed will bequeathing all lands to Thakur; provisions include endowment of immovable property to Sri Radhakrishnaji, wives as Mutawallis, committee of management, etc.
Ram Kuar (one wife) predeceased; Raj Kuar succeeded as Mutawalli till death in 1933.
First defendant (nephew Murlidhar) got possession as manager per will.

Appellant, distant agnate of Sheo Ghulam, alleged mismanagement and denial of public rights; moved District Court Sitapur under Religious and Charitable Endowments Act XIV of 1920, but declined as private.
Application to Advocate-General for sanction under s.92 CPC refused as private.
Appellant filed Regular Civil Suit No. 14 of 1944 for declaration that Thakurdwara is public temple.
First defendant contested, claimed private temple and idols, no public right.
Additional Civil Judge Sitapur dismissed suit on 25.11.1944 holding private temple for family worship.
District Judge Sitapur affirmed in Appeal No. 4 of 1945 on 30.05.1945.
Chief Court of Oudh affirmed in Second Appeal No. 365 of 1945 on 14.07.1948, granted certificate under s.109 CPC.
Villagers worshipped freely without interference; built at instance of villagers as no temple in village.
Pujari stopped outsiders during wife's puja due to purdah.
Consecration and installation with ceremonies per Sastras, lasted 7 days, including Kalasa Puja to Prathista; Prasadothsarga performed, not Uthsarga.
Idol installed in separate building on vacant site, not residential quarters; some idols permanently on pedestal; puja by appointed archaka.

legal_issues.text: Whether Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in village Bhadesia, District Sitapur is a private temple or a public one in which all Hindus are entitled to worship.

petitioner_arguments.text: Thakurdwara is public based on will (Exhibit A-1), public user without interference, ceremonies including Uthsarga/Prasadothsarga, built at villagers' instance, no temple in village.
Performance of Uthsarga conclusive for public dedication.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sanskrit texts on Sankalpa, Uthsarga, Prathista

respondent_arguments.text: Thakurdwara and idols private; built for family worship; public admitted as grace, not right; no interference during purdah puja.

court_reasoning.text: Question is mixed law and fact; principles: private trust for specific individuals, public for general public/class; dedication to idol abandons dominion for pious purposes benefiting worshippers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: True beneficiaries are worshippers, not idol; cardinal point is founder's intention for specified individuals or general public.

court_reasoning.text: Will (Exhibit A-1) reveals public intention: no male issue recital, committee with non-relatives, no restriction on appointments, clause barring heirs' claims, continuance beyond wives' life requires public beneficiaries.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Inconceivable to entrust strangers if for family only; endowment would fail otherwise.

court_reasoning.text: Public user consistent with public endowment since initial dedication to idol; not mere grace as in private start cases.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proof of user without interference relevant for public dedication.

court_reasoning.text: Ceremonies: Prathista (not Uthsarga) performed; Prathista takes place of Uthsarga for temples, dedicates to public; Prasadothsarga different.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Texts confirm no Uthsarga for temples; Prathista establishes public dedication.

court_reasoning.text: Other facts: separate building, permanent idols, appointed archaka, no prior temple, pleadings lack family-specific claim.

holdings.text: Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji in Bhadesia is a public temple.

precedents_cited.relevance: Mixed question of law and fact on dedication scope.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhupati Nath Smrititirtha v. Ram Lal Maitra
precedents_cited.relevance: Dedication to idol is abandonment for pious purposes benefiting worshippers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hindu Religious Endowments Board v. Yeeraraghavachariar
precedents_cited.relevance: Endowments benefit worshippers; public if for general public.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nabi Shirazi v. Province of Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: No children recital suggests public, not family.

precedents_cited.case_name: Babu Bhagwan Din v. Gir Har Saroon
precedents_cited.relevance: Public user insufficient if initially private grant to individual.
Public user presumes public if not initially private.

precedents_cited.case_name: Delroos Banoo Begum v. Nawab Syud Ashgur Ally Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate public building factor for public endowment.

statutes_cited.name: Religious and Charitable Endowments Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellant sought relief; declined as private

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Sanction refused; certificate granted for appeal

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; decrees of courts below set aside; declaration granted that Thakurdwara is public temple in terms of para 17(a) of plaint.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that Thakurdwara of Sri Radhakrishnaji is public temple where all Hindus entitled to worship.
outcome.costs: Costs of appellant in all courts out of trust properties.

key_quotes.text: The distinction between a private and a public trust is that whereas in the former the beneficiaries are specific individuals, in the latter they are the general public or a class thereof.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines core legal test for public vs private endowment.

key_quotes.text: When once it is understood that the true beneficiaries of religious endowments are not the idols but the worshippers, [...] the question whether an endowment is private or public presents no difficulty.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and beneficiaries of dedication.

key_quotes.text: We think that the will read as a whole indubitably reveals an intention on the part of the testator to dedicate the Thakurdwara to the public and not merely to the members of his family.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on interpretation of will.
